docs.lead_paragraph: FOR more than three decades, Dr. Irwin Redlener of New Rochelle, president of the Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, has worked on behalf of children who, usually because of their economic circumstances, are underserved by the health care system. Frustrating? Yes, he admits, but he hopes that today's prosperity will result in policies that will help the 20 million or so American children who are without health insurance or otherwise have problems obtaining health care.

headline.main: Q&A/Dr. Irwin Redlener; Making Health Care Better for Children

docs.abstract: Dr Irwin Redlener, president and co-founder of Children's Health Fund and president of Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Center in Bronx, answers questions on efforts to improve children's health care services in Westchester County, NY; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S 2:30 on a Monday morning, and things are just getting under way. A jazz quintet is playing up in front of the small subterranean room, which is filled nearly to capacity. Candlelight reflects from the decorations on the wall: dim photographs of jazz legends from days gone by, odd sections of brass instruments oxidized by years of smoky air. Seated around small round tables or on padded benches along the wall, people bob in time to the music, smiling and humming between sips of beer. No clear line divides performance from audience. Instead of playing on a stage, the musicians squeeze into a tiny area cleared around the beat-up baby grand piano. Even the band has blurry boundaries; halfway through a song, the tenor sax player hands his instrument to a man sitting on the sidelines. The man takes a solo without leaving his seat, then hands the sax back to his friend, who finishes the song with a reprise of the melody.

headline.main: Where the Solos Last Till Dawn; With Endless Music and Open Jams, Smalls Stands Out Among Jazz Clubs Like a Blue Note in a Major Scale

docs.abstract: Article on Smalls, jazz club on West 10th Street, Manhattan, where dusk-to-dawn concerts and jam sessions draw young players on nightly basis; list of other NYC jazz clubs, past and present; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Not long into his campaign appearances, Senator John McCain will often joke about two Arizona mentors, one from the right and one from the left. He recalls how a nostalgic Barry Goldwater once told him that if he had defeated Lyndon B. Johnson in the 1964 presidential race, then Mr. McCain would never have languished in a Vietnamese prison camp. ''I said, 'You're right, Barry. It would have been a Chinese prison camp,' '' Mr. McCain winds up. ''He was not amused by that.''

headline.main: Conservative Ideas Spoken With Populist Passion

docs.abstract: John McCain is increasingly seen by campaign audiences as presidential candidate who can reach across party lines and is hard to place along ideological spectrum, but puzzling truth is that, in 17 years in Congress, he has had rock-solid conservative voting record, except for defiance of Republican leaders on campaign finance reform and anti-tobacco legislation; photo; Christian Coalition gave him perfect scores until he dropped to 73 percent in 1998, while liberal Americans for Democratic Action has never given him more than 20 percent rating; McCain on campaign trail gives voice to passions that are more populist than traditionally conservative, and can sound remarkably like a Democrat in talking about working people without health insurance; what is clear on stump is that he yearns for middle ground even on issues like abortion, and wants dialogue across party lines, as in his friendship with fellow military hero John Kerry (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN America Online and Time Warner announced the biggest merger in history last week, it set off a furious, if predictable, debate that swept through the airwaves, chat rooms and hyperactive financial markets, which couldn't decide if it was a brilliant idea or a marriage made in cyberhell. Is it good for the country, many asked, for a single media conglomerate that already bestrides the print and cable world to also control America's most popular entrance ramp to the Internet?

headline.main: Ideas & Trends: Lost in Cyberspace; Whistling Past the New Economy

docs.abstract: Old economy dominates the debate in presidential campaign; candidates ignore the new digital economy of Internet and the news of America Online's acquisition of Time Warner; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With just 10 days to go before the Iowa caucuses, former Senator Bill Bradley sharpened his efforts today to portray Vice President Al Gore as a ''nibble around the edges'' politician, saying Mr. Gore was too willing ''to settle'' for small solutions for big problems. ''Some people say we cannot do big things,'' Mr. Bradley said before several hundred students, teachers and supporters in a high school auditorium here. ''We're a great country at the time of our greatest prosperity. And now is not the time to settle.''

headline.main: Eyes on Iowa, Bradley Jabs as Gore Holds Back Punch
headline.kicker: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE CONTEST IN IOWA

docs.abstract: Bill Bradley sharpens campaign attack in Iowa, portraying Al Gore as 'nibble around the edges' politician too willing to settle for small solutions to big problems; photo with students in Iowa; Gore keeps head down in New Hampshire, avoiding rallies and potential for criticism; Nebraska Sen Bob Kerrey campaigns with Bradley in Iowa (M)
